thread.title: 'Here, can I have your Metro ticket?': Can anything be done to stop ticket beggars?

author: Ian Johnson
title: 'Here, can I have your Metro ticket?': Can anything be done to stop ticket beggars?
text:
Gateshead Stadium Metro Station (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
As Enas Filimban entered the concourse, she recognised the four men coming towards her. 
They were beggars, who had previously pestered her for her Metro ticket . 
This time, when she declined, one made a comment about her hijab. 
“I was so afraid,” she recalled. 
“When I got home, I was shivering after what happened.” 
At Gateshead Stadium Metro station , where Enas was abused, locals say the ticket begging problem is out of control. 
They claim they are harassed, pestered and feel threatened to hand over their tickets - but feel nothing is being done about it. 
Exclusive Chronicle figures reveal that since the start of 2017, police have been called repeatedly over “persistent” and “aggressive” ticket beggars. 
Not one arrest has been made. Data suggests that if the culprits are found, they are moved along. 
Northumbria Police say while intimidating people is illegal, ticket begging isn’t. 
The force add while one persistent offender has been removed from the area, criminal action is “not necessarily” the way it wants to tackle the ticket beggars. 
Nexus, the Metro’s operator, say customers should refuse to hand over their ticket. 
But Ashleigh Harle said it isn’t always that simple. 
“When they hover over you when you have your card, it is intimidating,” said the 27-year-old, who lives near the station. 
“When I was working, I would be asked every week for my ticket, and when they are drunk you can feel quite vulnerable. 
“I feel more could definitely be done to stop it.” A metro ticket (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Nexus spends £1m a year on a dedicated Northumbria Police Metro Unit and has revenue protection officers - backed up by 600 CCTV cameras - operating across all 60 stations. 
But it makes no profit from the line, meaning fares would have to go up to offer extra security staff. 
There’s another option - the Withdrawal of Implied Permission (WIP) scheme - which they can use to ban beggars from the line. 
“One individual has also been removed from the area completely thanks to the proactive work of neighbourhood officers in the area and this has had an impact,” said a Northumbria Police spokesperson. 
“Nexus can issue a WIP to individuals who cause a nuisance on the Metro line and this bans them from the entire network. 
“This is just one option that can be used in the first instance and gives police the power to take action if individuals breach that order.” 
Nexus add that, with evidence, it is a tactic it would use again. 
A Nexus spokesman said: “We work closely with Northumbria Police to deal with anti-social behaviour and crime when it occurs on Metro, including aggressive begging. This is something we are targeting through joint actions including high visibility patrols.” 
And, despite locals claims, police claim ticket begging “is not something that is being reported regularly” by the public. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now 
Figures obtained by the Chronicle via the Freedom of Information data shows that, at Gateshead Stadium in 2017, that figure was higher. 
In one month alone there were seven, with one caller telling police he was “sick” of having to report ticket beggars. 
“I would tell the police about it on Facebook instead of calling,” added Ashleigh. 
“I would generally get a response along the lines of ‘we will check the CCTV’, but you never felt anything would be done.” 
A police community meeting will be held at The Salvation Army, in Sunderland Road, on March 29 with the public urged to raise any concerns then. 
Both Nexus and police insist they are “committed” to tackling anti-social behaviour on the line. 
But the force add: “It is important to recognise that some of these individuals are incredibly vulnerable and there are a number of complex factors that have led them to beg. 
“Our priority for these individuals is not necessarily criminal action, we will try to signpost them to support services so they can get the help they need.” Read More 'Brexit is a monstrosity': Pro-EU float mocking Tory MPs paraded in Newcastle 
However, for some of those who have to endure calls of ‘here, do you want to buy a ticket?’, tougher action is required. 
“It’s at the point now where you get (to the station) and expect to see someone begging,” added Enas. 
“One man is there every day and if he isn’t, you think he’s off sick. 
“It is very intimidating, and if there was just even a little bit more monitoring, it could make a big difference.” 
The Nexus spokesman added: “Anyone who commits an offence on Metro will be captured on our network of 600 CCTV cameras and will face prosecution. If any customer is approached for their used Metro ticket at any Metro station we advise them to refuse, and if they feel threatened they should report that to the police.” Like us on Facebook
